<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations&#151;Year Ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 Compared to Year Ended March&nbsp;31, 2004  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We had a net loss of $23,430,000, or $0.66 per diluted share, for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 as compared to net income of $12,635,000, or $0.36 per
diluted share, for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. Included in our net loss for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 were the following items before the effect of income taxes: a write down of
$5,123,000 of the carrying value of Boeing rotable spare parts which was partially offset by an unrealized gain on fuel hedges of $2,837,000. These items, net of income taxes, increased our net loss
by 4&cent; per diluted share. Included in our net income for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 were the following items before the effect of profit sharing and income taxes: $15,024,000 of
compensation received under the Appropriations Act offset by the write-off of deferred loan costs of $9,816,000 associated with the prepayment of all of a $70,000,000 government guaranteed </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=34,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=567300,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DM2116A.;7',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;11:31' -->
<A NAME="page_dm2116_1_35"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>loan;
a charge for Boeing aircraft and facility lease exit costs of $5,372,000; a loss of $1,838,000 on the sale of one Airbus aircraft in a sale-leaseback transaction and from the sale of
a spare engine and other assets; a write down of $3,560,000 of the carrying value of spare engines and rotable parts that support the Boeing 737-300 aircraft; and $1,152,000 of flight crew
training expenses related to the start-up of our new Frontier JetExpress regional jet relationship with Horizon. These items, net of income taxes and profit sharing, reduced net income by
12&cent; per diluted share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
mainline passenger yield per RPM was 11.03&cent; and 11.96&cent; for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and March&nbsp;31, 2004, respectively, or a decrease of
7.8%. Our length of haul was 990 and 919 miles for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and March&nbsp;31, 2004, respectively, or an increase of 7.7%. Our mainline average fare was $102 for the
year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 as compared to $104 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, a decrease of 1.9%. Our mainline yield per ASM ("RASM") for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and
March&nbsp;31, 2004 was 7.97&cent; and 8.56&cent;, respectively, a decrease of 6.9%. The decreases in the mainline average fare and mainline RASM were offset by an increase in our
mainline load factor to 72.3% for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 as compared to 71.6% for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, an increase of .07 points. In February&nbsp;2004, we capped all
fares to and from Denver at $314 one-way, excluding passenger facility, security or segment fees, with the exception of flights to Mexico and Anchorage, Alaska. The fare cap was a 25 to
50&nbsp;percent reduction from the February&nbsp;2003 caps of $399 and $499. Although this created downward pressure on our mainline passenger yield per RPM and average fare, we believe the effect
on our revenues was offset by an increase in passenger traffic. Pricing caps on airfare, as a policy, were eliminated shortly after fiscal year 2005 began. Additionally, we believe that our average
fare during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 was negatively impacted as a result of aggressive pricing actions by our competitors in all of the markets we serve and is systemic across the entire
industry. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
mainline CASM, for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 was 8.42&cent; and 8.41&cent;, respectively. Mainline CASM, excluding fuel for the years ended
March&nbsp;31, 2005
and 2004 were 6.38&cent; and 6.89&cent;, respectively, a decrease of .51&cent; or 7.4%. Our mainline CASM excluding fuel decreased during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005
primarily as a result of the realized benefits of efficiencies of scale associated with increasing capacity while controlling costs which resulted in a decrease in traffic and servicing costs of
..12&cent; and promotion and sales of .07&cent;. In addition, maintenance cost per ASM decreased by .15&cent; as a result of the reduction in our Boeing fleet that was replaced
with new Airbus A319 aircraft. Included in mainline CASM for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 was .09&cent; per ASM for profit sharing bonuses and 0.07&cent; for aircraft lease and
facility exit costs. As a result of our net loss for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, we did not accrue for bonuses. Mainline CASM also decreased as a result of an increase in our daily block
hour utilization as discussed below and economies of scale associated with lower increases in indirect costs as compared to the 27.4% increase in mainline ASMs&nbsp;over the prior comparable period. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, our average daily block hour utilization increased to 11.1 from 10.4 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, or 6.7%. The calculation of
our block hour utilization includes all aircraft that are on our operating certificate, which includes scheduled aircraft, as well as aircraft out of service for maintenance and operational spare
aircraft, and excludes aircraft removed permanently from revenue service or new aircraft not yet placed in revenue service. It excludes Frontier JetExpress aircraft operated by Horizon. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, our mainline break-even load factors were 75.0% and 68.8%, respectively, compared to our achieved passenger load factors
of 72.3% and 71.6%, respectively. Our mainline break-even load factor increased from the prior comparable period largely as a result of a decrease in our average fare to $102 during the
year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 from $104 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. At the passenger levels in effect during the fiscal year ending March&nbsp;31, 2005, the $2 decrease in
average fare equaled a revenue decrease of approximately $13,306,000&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=35,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=473456,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DM2116B.;6',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;11:31' -->
<A NAME="page_dm2116_1_36"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Small
fluctuations in our yield per revenue passenger mile or cost per available seat mile can significantly affect operating results because we, like other airlines, have high fixed
costs in relation to revenues. Airline operations are highly sensitive to various factors, including the actions of competing airlines and general economic factors, which can adversely affect our
liquidity, cash flows and results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Revenues  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our revenues are highly sensitive to changes in fare levels. Competitive fare pricing policies have a significant impact on our revenues. Because of the
elasticity of passenger demand, we believe that
increases in fares may at certain levels result in a decrease in passenger demand in many markets. We cannot predict future fare levels, which depend to a substantial degree on competitive factors and
the economy. When sale prices or other price changes are initiated by competitors in our markets, we believe that we must, in most cases, match those competitors in order to maintain our market share.
Passenger revenues are seasonal depending on the markets' locations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger Revenues&#151;Mainline.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger revenues from our mainline operations totaled $731,822,000 for the year
ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 compared to $615,390,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, or an increase of 18.9% on increased ASMs&nbsp;of 1,962,000, or 27.4%. Mainline passenger revenues
include revenues for reduced rate standby passengers, administrative fees, revenue recognized for tickets that are not used within one year from their issue dates and revenue recognized from our
co-branded credit card agreement. We carried 6,653,000 mainline revenue passengers during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 compared to 5,569,000 mainline revenue passengers during the
year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, an increase of 19.5%. We had an average of 44.9 aircraft in our mainline fleet during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 compared to an average of 37.3 mainline
aircraft during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, an increase of 20.4%. Mainline RPMs&nbsp;for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 were 6,587,589,000 compared to 5,120,587,000 for the year
ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, an increase of 28.6%. Our mainline load factor increased to 72.3% for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 from 71.6% for the prior comparable period, an increase of 0.7
points, or 1.0%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger Revenues&#151;Regional Partner.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regional partner revenues, consisting of revenues from Frontier JetExpress
operated by Horizon, totaled $84,269,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and totaled $11,191,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. Revenues of $25,155,000 from the Frontier JetExpress
service, formerly provided by Mesa, were netted against related expenses and included in "Other revenues" for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005. As such, the fiscal year 2004 amounts only represent
three months of service with a limited number of aircraft. The incremental revenue from passengers connecting to/from regional flights to mainline flights is included in our mainline passenger
revenue. Horizon began service January&nbsp;1, 2004 and replaced the Frontier JetExpress service formerly provided by Mesa. See footnote (2)&nbsp;in Item 6. "Selected Financial Data", which
explains the different accounting methods for our Frontier JetExpress operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo Revenues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo revenues, consisting of revenues from freight and mail service, totaled $4,958,000 and $8,077,000 for
the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively, representing 0.7% and 1.3%, respectively, of total mainline revenues, a decrease of 0.6%. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, we
determined that carrying mail for the United States Postal Service was not profitable and we terminated our contract effective July&nbsp;1, 2004. This adjunct to the passenger business is highly
competitive and depends heavily on aircraft scheduling, alternate competitive means of same day delivery service and schedule reliability. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Revenues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenues, comprised principally of LiveTV sales, net revenue from the Mesa codeshare agreement of
$1,717,000 (in 2004 only), liquor sales, ground handling fees, and excess baggage fees, totaled $12,591,000 and $9,021,000 or 1.7% and 1.4% of total operating revenues for the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=36,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=37378,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DM2116B.;6',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;11:31' -->
<A NAME="page_dm2116_1_37"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>years
ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Other revenue increased over the prior comparable period primarily as a result of an increase in LiveTV sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Expenses  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating expenses include those related to flight operations, aircraft and traffic servicing, maintenance, promotion and sales, Frontier JetExpress operations,
general and administrative and depreciation and amortization. Total operating expenses were $860,087,000 and $616,197,000, respectively, for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, and
represented 103.2% and 95.7% of total revenue, respectively. Operating expenses excluding expenses from our regional partner operations totaled $767,606,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005,
or 102.4% of total revenue, excluding regional partner revenues. Operating expenses excluding expenses from our regional partner totaled $601,563,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, or 95.1%
of total revenue, excluding regional partner revenues. Operating expenses increased as a percentage of revenue during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 largely a result of a 35.6% increase in our
aircraft fuel cost per gallon for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 as compared to the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salaries, Wages and Benefits.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We record salaries, wages and benefits within the specific expense category identified in our
statements of operations to which they pertain. Salaries, wages and benefits totaled $203,398,000 and $160,260,000 and were 27.1% and 25.3% of total revenues excluding regional partner revenues for
the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively, an increase of 26.9%. Salaries, wages and benefits increased over the prior period largely as a result of overall wage increases and an
increase in the number of employees to support our ASM growth of 27.4% during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005. Our employees increased from approximately 4,100 in March&nbsp;2004 to
approximately 4,500 in March&nbsp;2005, or 9.8%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Flight Operations.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Flight operations expenses of $132,023,000 and $105,255,000 were 17.6% and 16.6% of total revenue
excluding revenues from our regional partner operations for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively, an increase of 25.4%. Flight operations expenses include all expenses related
directly to the operation of the aircraft excluding depreciation of owned aircraft and lease expenses and including insurance expenses, pilot and flight attendant compensation, in-flight
catering, crew overnight expenses, flight dispatch and flight operations administrative expenses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft
insurance expenses totaled $10,219,000 (1.4% of total revenues excluding revenues from our regional partner operations) for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005. Aircraft
insurance expenses for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 were $9,950,000 (1.6% of total revenues excluding revenues from our regional partner operations). Aircraft insurance expenses decreased per
RPM as a result of less expensive war risk coverage that is presently provided by the FAA compared to the coverage that was previously provided by commercial underwriters combined with a 25% decrease
in our basic hull and liability insurance rates effective June&nbsp;7, 2004. The current FAA war risk policy is in effect until August&nbsp;31, 2005. We do not know whether the government will
extend the coverage beyond August&nbsp;2005, and if it does, how long the extension will last. We expect that if the government stops providing excess war risk coverage to the airline industry, the
premiums charged by aviation insurers for this coverage will be substantially higher than the premiums currently charged by the government or the coverage will not be available from reputable
underwriters. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pilot
and flight attendant salaries before payroll taxes and benefits totaled $72,487,000 and $53,358,000 or 9.7% and 8.7% of passenger revenue, excluding revenues from our regional
partner operations, for each of the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, or an increase of 35.9%. Pilot and flight attendant compensation for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 increased as a
result of a 20.4% increase in the average number of mainline aircraft in service combined with an increase of 28.2% in mainline block hours, a general wage increase in flight attendant and pilot
salaries and additional crew required to replace those who were attending training on the Airbus equipment. We pay pilot and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=37,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=686455,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DM2116B.;6',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;11:31' -->
<A NAME="page_dm2116_1_38"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>flight
attendant salaries for training, consisting of approximately six weeks each, prior to scheduled increases in service, which can cause the compensation expense during such periods to appear high
relative to the average number of aircraft in service. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft Fuel Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expenses include both the direct cost of fuel including taxes as well as the cost of
delivering fuel into the aircraft. Aircraft fuel costs of $185,821,000 for 131,906,000 gallons used and $108,863,000 for 104,799,000 gallons used resulted in an average fuel cost of $1.41 and $1.04
per gallon for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Aircraft fuel expenses represented 24.8% and 17.2% of total revenue, excluding revenue from our regional partner
operations, for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Fuel prices are subject to change weekly, as we purchase a very small portion in advance for inventory. We initiated a
fuel-hedging program in late November&nbsp;2002, which decreased fuel expense by $7,605,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and decreased fuel expense by $1,387,000 for the year
ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. Fuel hedging gains include unrealized fuel gains of $2,837,000 and $469,000 in 2005 and 2004, respectively. Fuel consumption for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and
2004 averaged 722 and 736 gallons per block hour, respectively, or a decrease of 1.9%. Fuel consumption per block hour decreased during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 from the prior year because
of the more fuel-efficient Airbus aircraft added to our fleet coupled with the reduction in our Boeing fleet, which had higher fuel burn rates, partially offset by the increase in our load
factors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft Lease Expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease expenses totaled $87,096,000 (11.6% of total revenues excluding revenues from our
regional partner operations) and $70,061,000 (11.1% of total revenues excluding revenues from our regional partner operations) for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004,
respectively, or an increase of 24.3%. The increase is a result of an increase in the average number of leased aircraft to 30.9 from 26.0, or 18.8%, during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005
compared to the same period in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft and Traffic Servicing.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses were $129,470,000 and $110,378,000 (an increase of
17.3%) for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively, and represented 17.3% and 17.5% of total revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations. Aircraft and
traffic servicing expenses include all expenses incurred at airports, including landing fees, facilities rental, station labor, ground handling expenses (passenger and cargo) and interrupted trip
expenses associated with delayed or cancelled flights. Interrupted trip expenses are amounts paid to other airlines to reaccommodate passengers as well as hotel, meal and other incidental expenses.
Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses increase with the addition of new cities and departures to our route system. As of March&nbsp;31, 2005, we served 39 cities with mainline service compared to
38 as of March&nbsp;31, 2004, or an increase of 2.6%. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, our mainline departures increased to 72,888 from 61,812 during the year ended March&nbsp;31,
2004, or 17.9%. Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses were $1,776 per mainline departure for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 as compared to $1,786 per mainline departure for the year ended
March&nbsp;31, 2004, or a decrease of $10 per mainline departure. Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses decreased per mainline departure principally as a result of better on-time
performance and fewer expenses paid for delayed or misconnected flights. In addition, commencing in the July&nbsp;2004 we no longer carried U.S. mail and our ground handling expenses decreased
accordingly. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance expenses for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 of $76,679,000 and $70,444,000,
respectively, were 10.2% and 11.1% of total revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations, an increase of 8.9%. These include all labor, parts and supplies expenses related to the
maintenance of the aircraft. Maintenance costs per block hour for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 were $420 and $494 per block hour, respectively, a decrease of 15.0%. Maintenance cost
per block hour decreased as a result of the addition of new Airbus aircraft that are less costly to maintain than our older Boeing aircraft, offset by return condition expenses related to the 7 Boeing
aircraft returned and/or retired in fiscal year 2005. The owned Airbus fleet is new and we are experiencing a "maintenance holiday". As our Airbus aircraft age, they will require more maintenance and
maintenance expenses will increase. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=38,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=684552,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DM2116B.;6',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;11:31' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do2116_1_39"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Promotion and Sales.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Promotion and sales expenses totaled $76,462,000 and $65,322,000 and were 10.2%
and 10.3% of total
revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations, for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. These include advertising expenses, telecommunications expenses,
wages and benefits for reservation agents and reservations supervision, marketing management and sales personnel, credit card fees, travel agency commissions and computer reservations costs. During
the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, promotion and sales expenses per mainline passenger decreased to $11.49 compared to $11.73 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, a decrease of 2.0%. Promotion
and sales expenses per mainline passenger decreased as a result of variable expenses that are based on lower average fares and economies of scale associated with our growth. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General and Administrative.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General and administrative expenses for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004 totaled
$48,351,000 and $36,750,000, and were 6.5% and 5.8% of total revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations, respectively, or an increase of 31.6%. General and administrative
expenses include the wages and benefits for several of our executive officers and various other administrative personnel including legal, accounting, information technology, aircraft procurement,
corporate communications, training and human resources and other expenses associated with these departments. Employee health benefits, accrued vacation and bonus expenses, general insurance expenses
including worker's compensation and write-offs associated with credit card and check fraud are also included in general and administrative expenses. Our employees increased from
approximately 4,100 in March&nbsp;2004 to approximately 4,500 in March&nbsp;2005, or 9.8%. Accordingly, we experienced increases in our human resources, training, information technology, and
health insurance benefit expenses. As a result of our pre-tax loss for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, we did not accrue bonuses which are solely based on profitability. General and
administrative expenses also include $2,960,000 of expenses related to the conversion to our new reservation system and $603,000 of out-of-pocket costs to comply with the
Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, we accrued $2,436,000 for employee performance bonuses, or 0.4% of total revenues. General and administrative expenses also
increased with a general increase in the cost of providing health insurance. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regional Partner Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regional partner expenses for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 totaled $92,481,000, and were
109.7% of total regional partner revenues compared to expenses of $14,634,000, or 130.8%, of total regional partner revenue for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. Regional partner expenses include
all direct costs associated with Frontier JetExpress operated by Horizon. Horizon began service January&nbsp;1, 2004 and replaced the JetExpress service formerly provided by Mesa. During the year
ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, $23,438,000 in Mesa expenses were netted against related revenues and included in "Other revenues". See footnote (2)&nbsp;in "Selected Financial Data", which explains
the different accounting methods for our Frontier JetExpress operations for Horizon and Mesa. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, we incurred $1,152,000 for flight crew training costs and
other related costs associated with the start-up of our regional partnership with Horizon. We do not expect to incur these costs going forward unless we were to add additional aircraft
under the Horizon agreement, which we do not contemplate at this time. For additional information about Frontier JetExpress, see Note&nbsp;1 of the Notes to the Financial Statements. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment and Other Related Charges.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 we recorded additional impairments and
other related charges totaling $5,123,000 on the carrying value of our Boeing 737 expendable inventory, rotable parts and a spare engine as a result of further market declines and the results of
actual sales. Included in this amount are estimated selling costs that we expect to pay on the sale of our assets held for sale totaling $541,000. We believe the decline in resale values of parts for
the less fuel-efficient Boeing 737 aircraft was due in part to increasing fuel prices during the past year. The impairment on spare and rotables is a result of further market declines for
Boeing parts coupled with the results of actual sales history. In August&nbsp;2004, we began selling our Boeing spare parts. Our analysis of these sales compared to the impaired value of these parts
as of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=39,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=447335,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116A.;8',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_do2116_1_40"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>December&nbsp;31,
2004 indicated that we were selling these rotable parts at approximately 90% of the carrying value. The impairment recorded for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 was $3,560,000,
which also related to the impairment of Boeing spare engines and rotable parts that supported the Boeing 737 aircraft. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation expenses of $26,498,000 and $23,720,000, an increase of 11.7%, were approximately 3.5% and 3.8% of
total revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations, for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and 2004, respectively. These expenses include depreciation of aircraft and aircraft
components, office equipment, ground station equipment and other fixed assets. Depreciation expense increased over the prior year largely as a result of an increase in the average number of Airbus
A318 and A319 aircraft owned from an average of 11.4 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 to an average of 14.0 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, an increase of 22.8%. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Nonoperating Income (Expense).</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net nonoperating expenses totaled $9,391,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 compared
to net nonoperating expense of $7,025,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. Interest income increased to $3,758,000 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 from $2,074,000 for the prior
period due to an increase in investment rates earned on investments. Interest expense was $13,184,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 as compared to $13,961,000 for the prior period. Interest
expense for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 included the interest expense associated with a $70,000,000 government guaranteed loan we obtained in February&nbsp;2002 and subsequently repaid in
December&nbsp;2003. The decrease in interest was due to the repayment of this loan, which was offset by an increase in interest expense associated with the financing of additional aircraft purchased
since March&nbsp;31, 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Tax Expense (Benefit).</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recorded an income tax benefit of $12,408,000 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 at
a 34.6% rate compared to income tax expense of $7,822,000 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 at a 38.2% effective tax rate. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company's tax
benefit was at a federal rate of 35.0% plus the blended state rate of 3.0% (net of federal benefit) and was decreased by the tax effect of permanent differences of 2.0%. During the year ended
March&nbsp;31, 2005, the Company recorded a valuation allowance of $262,000 against certain state net operating loss carryforwards since it was more likely than not that the tax benefit was not
going to be realized due to the lack of taxable income in these jurisdictions, which approximated 1.0%. During the year ended
March&nbsp;31, 2004 the Company recorded a $558,000 reduction to income tax expense as a result of an adjustment to deferred income taxes provided for in prior years, which approximated 3%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations&#151;Year Ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 Compared to Year Ended March&nbsp;31, 2003  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We had net income of $12,635,000 or 36&cent; per diluted share for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 as compared to a net loss of $22,843,000 or
77&cent; per diluted share for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. Included in our net income for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 were the following items before the effect of profit
sharing and income taxes: $15,024,000 of compensation received under the Appropriations Act offset by the write-off of deferred loan costs of $9,816,000 associated with the prepayment of
all of the government guaranteed loan; a charge for Boeing aircraft and facility lease exit costs of $5,372,000; a loss of $1,838,000 on the sale of one Airbus aircraft in a sale-leaseback
transaction and from the sale of a spare engine; a write down of $3,560,000 of the carrying value of spare engines and rotable parts that support the Boeing 737-300 aircraft; and
$1,152,000 of flight crew training expenses related to the start-up of our new Frontier JetExpress regional jet relationship with Horizon. These items, net of income taxes and profit
sharing, reduced net income by 12&cent; per diluted share. Our net loss for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 included a $2,011,000 after-tax credit for the cumulative effect of
a change in accounting for major aircraft overhauls from the accrual method to the expense as incurred method. The net loss before the cumulative effect of the change in accounting was $24,854,000, or
$0.84 per common share. Our net loss for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 included the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=40,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=934970,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116A.;8',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_do2116_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>following
items on a pre-tax and profit sharing basis: the cost associated with the early extinguishment of debt totaling $1,774,000 and a write-down of the carrying values of
the Boeing spare aircraft parts totaling $2,478,000. These items, net of income taxes and profit sharing, increased our net loss by 9&cent; per diluted share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
mainline passenger yield per RPM was 11.96&cent; and 12.74&cent; for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and March&nbsp;31, 2003, respectively, or a decrease of
6.1%. Our length of haul was 919 and 917 miles for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and March&nbsp;31, 2003, respectively, or an increase of .2%. Our mainline average fare was $104 for the year
ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 as compared to $109 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, a decrease of 4.6%. The decrease in the average fare is offset by an increase in our mainline load factor to
71.6% for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 as compared to 59.9% for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, an increase of 11.7 points. As part of our new fare structure, which we implemented in
February&nbsp;2003, our highest-level business fares were initially reduced by 25 to 45&nbsp;percent, and our lowest available walk-up fares were reduced by 38 to 77&nbsp;percent.
This fare structure was comprised of six fare categories and capped all fares to and from Denver at $399 or $499 one-way, excluding passenger facility, security or segment fees, depending
on length of haul. Although this has created downward pressure on our mainline passenger yield per RPM and average fare, we believe the effect on our revenues was offset by an increase in passenger
traffic. Our mainline RASM for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and March&nbsp;31, 2003 was 8.56&cent; and
7.63&cent;, respectively, an increase of 12.2%. Additionally, we believe that our average fare during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 was negatively impacted as a result of intense
competition from United, a carrier operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, which is our principal competitor at DIA. We also believe that passenger traffic during the year ended
March&nbsp;31, 2003 was impacted by the threat of war with Iraq, which began in March&nbsp;2003. During March&nbsp;2003, the Denver area also experienced an unusual blizzard, which caused DIA to
be closed for approximately two days. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
mainline CASM for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 was 8.41&cent; and 8.33&cent;, respectively, an increase of .08&cent; or 1.0%. Mainline CASM
excluding fuel for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 was 6.89&cent; and 6.90&cent;, respectively, a decrease of .01&cent; or .3%. Our mainline CASM increased during
the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 as a result of an increase in the average price of fuel per gallon from 96&cent; to $1.04 or an increase of .09&cent; per ASM; an increase in
aircraft and traffic servicing expenses combined with sales and promotions expenses of .13&cent; as a result of the increase in the number of passengers we served and general increases in DIA
facility charges as well as related increases in sales and promotion expenses for booking fees associated with the increase in passengers, the ongoing costs of LiveTV service of .04&cent;; and
an increase in general and administrative expenses of .09&cent; as a result of the bonus accrual associated with our return to profitability and an increase in health insurance costs. Mainline
CASM also increased over the prior comparable period .07&cent; for costs associated with aircraft lease and facility exit costs and .02&cent; for a loss on the sale-leaseback
of an aircraft. These increases were partially offset by a decrease of .20&cent; in aircraft lease expense as a result of replacing four leased aircraft with four additional purchased aircraft,
offset by an increase in related depreciation expense of .04&cent; and a decrease of .22&cent; in maintenance expense principally as a result of the reduction in the number of aircraft
in our Boeing fleet that were replaced with new Airbus A319 and A318 aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, our average daily block hour utilization increased to 10.4 from 9.8 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. The calculation of our block
hour utilization includes all aircraft that are on our operating certificate, which includes scheduled aircraft, as well as aircraft out of service for maintenance and operational spare aircraft, and
excludes aircraft removed permanently from revenue service or new aircraft not yet placed in revenue service. It also excludes Frontier JetExpress aircraft operated by Horizon. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, our mainline break-even load factors were 68.8% and 65.0%, respectively, compared to our achieved passenger load factors
of 71.6% and 59.9%. Our </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=41,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=784992,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116A.;8',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_do2116_1_42"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>mainline
break-even load factor increased from the prior comparable period largely as a result of a decrease in our average fare to $104 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 from
$109 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Revenues  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger Revenues&#151;Mainline.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger revenues from our mainline operations totaled $615,390,000 for the year
ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 compared to $460,188,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, or an increase of 33.7%, on increased ASMs&nbsp;of 1,140,479,000, or 19.0%. Passenger revenues include
revenues for reduced rate standby passengers, administrative fees, and revenue recognized for tickets that are not used within one year from their issue dates. We carried 5,569,000 revenue passengers
during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 compared to 3,926,000 revenue passengers during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, an increase of 41.8%. We had an average of 37.3 aircraft in our
mainline fleet during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 compared to an average of 33.8 aircraft during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, an increase of 10.4%. RPMs&nbsp;for the year ended
March&nbsp;31, 2004 were 5,120,587,000 compared to 3,599,553,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, an increase of 42.3%. Our load factor increased to 71.6% for the year ended
March&nbsp;31, 2004 from 59.9% for the prior comparable period, an increase of 11.7 points, or 19.5%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Passenger Revenues&#151;Regional Partner.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regional partner revenues, consisting of revenues from Frontier JetExpress
operated by Horizon, totaled $11,191,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and none for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. Horizon began service January&nbsp;1, 2004 and replaced the
Frontier JetExpress service formerly provided by Mesa. Revenues from the Frontier JetExpress service, formerly provided by Mesa of $25,155,000 and $1,608,000, were netted against related expenses and
included in "Other revenues" for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. See footnote (2)&nbsp;in Item 6. "Selected Financial Data", which explains the different accounting
methods for our Frontier JetExpress operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo Revenues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cargo revenues, consisting of revenues from freight and mail service, totaled $8,077,000 and $5,557,000 for
the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively, representing 1.3% and 1.2%, respectively, of total mainline revenues, an increase of 45.3%. Cargo revenues increased in fiscal year 2004
over the prior comparable periods as a result of our contract to carry mail under a contract with the United States Postal Service that began in June&nbsp;2003. We terminated the US Postal Service
contract effective July&nbsp;1, 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Revenues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other revenues, comprised principally of LiveTV sales, net revenue from the Mesa codeshare agreement, liquor
sales, ground handling fees, and excess baggage fees, totaled $9,021,000 and $4,191,000 or 1.4% and .9% of total operating revenues for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively.
Other revenue increased over the prior comparable period predominately as a result of LiveTV sales and the net loss of $706,000 recorded in 2003 for the Mesa code share agreement compared to net
revenue of $1,717,000 in 2004. LiveTV sales commenced during the fourth fiscal quarter for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Operating Expenses  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total operating expenses were $616,197,000 and $500,727,000, respectively, for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, and represented 95.7% and 106.6% of
total revenue, respectively. Operating expenses excluding expenses from our regional partner operations totaled $601,562,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, or 95.1% of total revenue,
excluding regional partner revenues. Operating expenses decreased as a percentage of revenue during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 as a result of an increase in total revenue as compared to the
year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=42,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=876727,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116A.;8',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_do2116_1_43"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salaries, Wages and Benefits.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Salaries, wages and benefits totaled $160,260,000 and $125,847,000 and were 25.3% and 26.8% of
total revenues excluding regional partner revenues for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively, an increase of 27.3%. Salaries, wages and benefits increased over the prior
comparable periods largely as a result of our bonus accrual due to our return to profitability, overall wage increases, and an increase in the number of employees to support our ASM growth of 19.0%
during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 as well as the ASM growth that we expected for fiscal year 2005. Our employees increased from approximately 3,160 in March&nbsp;2003 to approximately
4,100 in March&nbsp;2004, or 29.7%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Flight Operations.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Flight operations expenses of $105,255,000 and $85,675,000 were 16.6% and 18.2% of total revenue excluding
revenues from our regional partner operations for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively, an increase of 22.9%. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft
insurance expenses totaled $9,950,000 (1.6% of total revenues excluding revenues from our regional partner operations) for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004. Aircraft
insurance expenses for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 were $11,095,000 (2.4% of total revenues excluding revenues from our regional partner operations). Aircraft insurance expenses decreased per
RPM as a result of less expensive war risk coverage that is presently provided by the FAA compared to the coverage that was previously provided by commercial underwriters combined with a 30% decrease
in our basic hull and liability insurance rates effective June&nbsp;7, 2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pilot
and flight attendant salaries before payroll taxes and benefits totaled $53,358,000 and $42,982,000 or 8.7% and 9.3% of passenger revenue, excluding revenues from our regional
partner operations, for each of the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, or an increase of 24.1%. Pilot and flight attendant compensation for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 increased as a
result of a 10.4% increase in the average number of mainline aircraft in service and an increase of 18.4% in mainline block hours, respectively, a general wage increase in flight attendant and pilot
salaries and additional crew required to replace those who were attending training on the Airbus equipment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft Fuel Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft fuel expenses include both the direct cost of fuel including taxes as well as the cost of
delivering fuel into the aircraft. Aircraft fuel costs of $108,863,000 for 104,799,000 gallons used and $86,064,000 for 89,236,000 gallons used resulted in an average fuel cost of $1.04 and
96&cent; per gallon for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. Aircraft fuel expenses represented 17.2% and 18.3% of total revenue, excluding revenue from our regional
partner operations, for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. We initiated a fuel hedging program in late November&nbsp;2002, which decreased fuel expense by $1,387,000 for
the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and $558,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. Fuel hedging gains include an unrealized fuel gain of $469,000 in the fiscal year ended 2004 and an
unrealized fuel loss of $167,000 in the fiscal year ended 2003. Fuel consumption for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 averaged 736 and 742 gallons per block hour, respectively, or a
decrease of .8%. Fuel consumption per block hour decreased during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 from the prior year because of the more fuel-efficient Airbus aircraft added to our
fleet coupled with the reduction in our Boeing fleet, which had higher fuel burn rates, partially offset by the increase in our load factors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft Lease Expenses.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft lease expenses totaled $70,061,000 (11.1% of total revenues excluding revenues from our
regional partner operations) and $70,239,000 (15.0% of total revenues excluding revenues from our regional partner operations) for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively, or a
decrease of .3%. The decrease is a result of a decrease in the average number of leased aircraft to 26.0 from 27.9, or 6.8%, during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 compared to the same period in
2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft and Traffic Servicing.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses were $110,378,000 and $86,448,000 (an increase of
27.7%) for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively, and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=43,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=388809,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116A.;8',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_do2116_1_44"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>represented
17.5% and 18.4% of total revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations. Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses increase with the addition of new cities and departures
to our route system. As of March&nbsp;31, 2004, we served 43 cities compared to 38 as of March&nbsp;31, 2003, or an increase of 13.2%. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, our mainline
departures increased to 61,812 from 53,081 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, or 16.4%. Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses were $1,786 per departure for the year ended March&nbsp;31,
2004 as compared to $1,629 per departure for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, or an increase of $157 per departure. Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses increased per departure as a result of
general increases in airport rents and landing fees and a 41.9% increase in mainline passengers for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 as compared to the prior year. Certain airport facility rent
charges are calculated using the numbers of originating and departing passengers, as well as additional personnel required to handle the increased number of passengers. Additionally, cargo (including
mail) revenue increased 45.3% for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 as compared to the prior year. Aircraft and traffic servicing expenses increase with increases in passengers and cargo handling.
We also experienced higher landing fees associated with the Airbus aircraft, which have higher landing weights than the Boeing aircraft. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance expenses for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 of $70,444,000 and $73,081,000,
respectively, were 11.1% and 15.6% of total revenues, excluding revenues from our
regional partner operations, a decrease of 3.6%. Maintenance costs per block hour for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 were $494 and $608 per block hour, respectively, a decrease of
18.8%. Maintenance cost per block hour decreased as a result of the addition of new Airbus aircraft that are less costly to maintain than our older Boeing aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Promotion and Sales.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Promotion and sales expenses totaled $65,322,000 and $53,032,000 and were 10.3% and 11.3% of total
revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations, for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, we reduced advertising
expenditures in order to apply those funds toward our new branding campaign that was scheduled to begin in March&nbsp;2003. Due to the commencement of the hostilities in Iraq, we postponed the roll
out of our branding campaign until May&nbsp;2003. Additionally, during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, we became heavily involved in sports team sponsorships as part of our branding awareness
initiative. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, promotion and sales expenses per mainline passenger decreased to $11.73 compared to $13.51 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, a decrease
of 13.2%. Promotion and sales expenses per passenger decreased as a result of variable expenses that are based on lower average fares, the elimination of substantially all travel agency commissions
effective on tickets sold after May&nbsp;31, 2002, and economies of scale associated with our growth. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General and Administrative.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General and administrative expenses for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003 totaled
$36,750,000 and $26,061,000, and were 5.8% and 5.6% of total revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations, respectively, or an increase of 41.0%. During the year ended
March&nbsp;31, 2004, we accrued $2,436,000 for employee performance bonuses, or .4% of total revenues. Bonuses are based on profitability. As a result of our pre-tax loss for the year
ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, we did not accrue bonuses. Our employees increased from approximately 3,160 in March&nbsp;2003 to approximately 4,100 in March&nbsp;2004, or 29.7%. Accordingly, we
experienced increases in our human resources, training, information technology, and health insurance benefit expenses. General and administrative expenses also increased with a general increase in the
cost of providing health insurance. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regional Partner Expense.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Regional partner expenses for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 totaled $14,634,000, and were
130.8% of total regional partner revenues. Horizon began service January&nbsp;1, 2004 and replaced the JetExpress service formerly provided by Mesa. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 and
through December&nbsp;31, 2004, expenses were netted against related revenues associated with Mesa and included in other revenues. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, $23,438,000 </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=44,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=723929,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116A.;8',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_do2116_1_45"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>and
$2,314,000, respectively, in Mesa expenses were netted against related revenues and included in "Other revenues". See footnote (2)&nbsp;in "Selected Financial Data", which explains the different
accounting methods for our Frontier JetExpress operations for Horizon and Mesa</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> During year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, we incurred $1,152,000 for
flight crew training costs and other related costs associated with the start-up of our regional partnership with Horizon. For additional information about Frontier JetExpress, see
Note&nbsp;1 of the Notes to the Financial Statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft Lease and Facility Exit Costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, we ceased using three of our Boeing
737-200 leased aircraft, two of which had lease terminations in October&nbsp;2003 and one with a lease termination date in October&nbsp;2005. In August&nbsp;2003, we closed our
maintenance facility in El Paso, Texas, which had a lease termination date in August&nbsp;2007. As a result of these transactions we recorded a pre-tax charge of $5,372,000. This amount
includes the estimated fair value of the remaining lease payments and the write off of the unamortized leasehold improvements on the aircraft and the facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Losses on Sales of Assets, net.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, we incurred losses totaling $1,838,000 on the
sales of assets, which included a loss of $1,323,000 on the sale-leaseback of an Airbus A319 aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment and Other Related Charges.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment and other related charges for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 was
$3,560,000 compared to $2,478,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. These impairments relate to the write-down of the spare parts inventory that supports the Boeing 737 aircraft. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation expenses of $23,720,000 and $17,650,000, an increase of 34.4%, were approximately 3.8% and 3.7% of
total revenues, excluding revenues from our regional partner operations, for the years ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 and 2003, respectively. Depreciation expense increased over the prior year largely as
a result of an increase in the average number of Airbus aircraft owned from an average of 6.3 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 to an average of 11.4 for the year ended March&nbsp;31,
2004, an increase of 81.0%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Nonoperating Income (Expense).</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net nonoperating expenses totaled $7,025,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 compared
to net nonoperating expense of $8,718,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003. Interest income increased to $2,074,000 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 from $1,883,000 for the prior
period due to an increase in invested cash. Interest expense increased to $13,961,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 from $8,041,000 for the prior period as a result of interest expense
associated with the financing of additional aircraft purchased since March&nbsp;31, 2003 and the government guaranteed loan we obtained in February&nbsp;2003 which we subsequently repaid in
December&nbsp;2003. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
completed a public offering of 5,050,000 shares of common stock in September&nbsp;2003. Under the terms of our government guaranteed loan, we were required to make a prepayment of
the loan equal to 60% of the net proceeds from the offering. As a result, we prepaid approximately $48,418,000 on the loan. In December&nbsp;2003, we repaid the remaining loan balance due of
$11,582,000. As a result of paying off the government guaranteed loan, we wrote off approximately $9,816,000 of deferred loan costs associated with the prepayment amount. Of this amount, approximately
$8,053,000 represented the unamortized portion of the value assigned to the warrants issued to ATSB and to two other guarantors in connection with the loan transaction. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Offsetting
these nonoperating expenses during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 is pre-tax compensation of $15,024,000 as a result of payments under the Appropriations Act
for expenses and foregone revenue related to aviation security. We received a total of $15,573,000 in May&nbsp;2003, of which we paid $549,000 to Mesa Airlines for the revenue passengers Mesa
carried as Frontier JetExpress. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, we completed a sale-leaseback transaction of one of our purchased aircraft and paid off the loan that was collateralized by this
aircraft. As a result, we incurred $1,774,000 in costs associated with the early extinguishment of this debt. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=45,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=1041049,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116B.;7',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_do2116_1_46"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Tax Expense (Benefit).</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recorded income tax expense of $7,822,000 during the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 at a
38.2% effective tax rate, compared to an income tax benefit of $14,655,000 for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003, at a 37.1% effective tax rate. During the ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, the
Company's tax expense was at a federal rate of 35.0% plus the blended state rate of 3.0% (net of federal benefit) and was increased by the tax effect of permanent differences of 3.0%. During the year
ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 the Company recorded a $558,000 reduction to income tax expense as a result of an adjustment to deferred income taxes provided for in prior years, which approximated 3.0%.
The expected benefit for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2003 was at a federal rate of 35.0% plus the blended state rate of 3.7% (net of federal tax benefit) and was reduced by the tax effect of
permanent differences of 1.0%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our liquidity depends to a large extent on the number of passengers who fly with us, the fares we charge, our operating and capital expenditures, our financing
activities, and the cost of fuel. We depend on lease or mortgage-style financing to acquire all of our aircraft, including 20 additional Airbus aircraft that as of March&nbsp;31, 2005 are scheduled
for delivery through March&nbsp;2008. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
had cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments of $174,795,000 and $190,609,000 at March&nbsp;31, 2005 and March&nbsp;31, 2004, respectively. At
March&nbsp;31, 2005, total current assets were $275,550,000 as compared to $233,850,000 of total current liabilities, resulting in working capital of $41,700,000. At March&nbsp;31, 2004, total
current assets were $269,733,000 as compared to $181,659,000 of total current liabilities, resulting in working capital of $88,074,000. The decrease in our working capital from March&nbsp;31, 2004
is largely a result of capital expenditures and debt principal payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating activities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash provided by operating activities for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 was $19,240,000. This is
attributable to our net loss adjusted for non-cash charges and credits
and changes in working capital accounts. Our restricted investments increased largely as a result of increased collateral requirements for our bankcard processor associated with the increase in our
air traffic liability and an increase in collateral for our workers' compensation insurance. Prepaid expenses increased principally as a result of an increase in fuel deposits (due to the increase in
the price of fuel and an increase in fuel consumption associated with the increase in block hours flown) and prepaid expenses related to passenger expenses increased due to the increase in passenger
traffic over the prior year. Additionally, prepaid aircraft rents increased as a result of the net increase of eight leased aircraft we took delivery of during the year. Inventories increased as a
result of an increase in the value of our fuel inventory and for the increase in the number of aircraft in our fleet. Our air traffic liability increased as a result of the growth of our business
associated with the increase in the number of aircraft in our fleet and the associated increase in the number of passengers we carried. Our accrued expenses increased as a result of increases in
employee benefits associated with the increase in the number of employees, increases in health care expenses, and increases in passenger related taxes associated with our increase in revenue and
passengers carried. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
provided by operating activities for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 was $128,018,000. This is attributable to our net income adjusted for non-cash charges and
credits and changes in working capital accounts. Our air traffic liability increased as a result in the growth of our business associated with the increase in the number of aircraft in our fleet
coupled with the increase in the number of passengers we carried in excess of our increased capacity. Our accrued expenses increased as a result of increases in employee benefits associated with the
increase in the number of employees and increases in health care expenses, the bonus accrual for our employees as a result of our profitability and increases in passenger related taxes associated with
our increase in revenue and passengers carried. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investing Activities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash provided by investing activities for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 was $14,841,000.
Aircraft lease and purchase deposits made during the period were $21,436,000 which was offset by deposits returned or applied to aircraft purchases of $23,008,000. Capital expenditures were </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=46,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=917075,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116B.;7',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<A NAME="page_do2116_1_47"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>$128,776,000
for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 and included the purchase of one Airbus A318 aircraft; and two Airbus A319 aircraft and one spare engine that were delivered to us and that we
sold in sale-leaseback transactions. Additionally, capital expenditures included the purchase of LiveTV equipment, rotable aircraft components, aircraft improvements, ground equipment, and
equipment related to our new reservation system. We applied pre-delivery payments totaling $6,412,000 for the purchase of an Airbus A318 aircraft to the purchase of that aircraft, and the
pre-delivery deposits totaling $14,716,000 for the two Airbus A319 aircraft were returned to us upon sale of the aircraft. We received $80,963,000 from the sale of the two new A319
aircraft and two spare engines that we sold in sale-leaseback transactions, two spare engines for our Boeing fleet and other Boeing spare parts. We also sold $57,600,000 of
short-term securities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
used in investing activities for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004 was $193,576,000. Aircraft lease and purchase deposits made during this period were $39,987,000, which was
offset by deposits returned of $33,541,000. Restricted investments decreased by $2,444,000 which was associated with collateral on returned aircraft and new aircraft deliveries where we substituted
cash security deposits in lieu of the
letters of credit that were previously in place. We also had net purchases totaling $55,265,000 of short-term securities. We used $134,651,000 for the purchase of four additional Airbus
aircraft, aircraft leasehold improvements including LiveTV, ground equipment to support increased below-wing operations, and computer equipment, including scanning equipment for our new
mail transportation requirements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing Activities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash provided by financing activities for the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 was $7,705,000. During
the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005, we borrowed $22,000,000 for the purchase of one Airbus A318 aircraft and paid $18,373,000 of debt principal payments on our 14 owned aircraft. During the year
ended March&nbsp;31,2005 we also had short-term borrowings of $5,000,000 under a revolving line of credit, received $349,000 from the exercise of common stock options and paid 1,271,000
of fees for debt financing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2004, we completed a public offering of 5,050,000 shares of our common stock. We received $81,077,000, net of offering expenses, from the sale of
these shares and we also received $1,001,000 from the exercise of common stock options. We borrowed $98,500,000 to finance the purchase of four Airbus aircraft and made principal repayments on debt of
$83,325,000. In July&nbsp;2003, we received an income tax refund from the Internal Revenue Service totaling $26,574,000 and prepaid $10,000,000 on our government guaranteed loan upon receipt of this
refund. In September&nbsp;2003, we used $48,418,000 of the proceeds from the stock offering to prepay a portion of the government guaranteed loan. Both prepayments were required by the loan
agreement. In December&nbsp;2003, we repaid the remaining loan balance due of $11,582,000. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Other Items that Impact our Liquidity  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2005, we placed in production a Sabre,&nbsp;Inc. customer automation solution, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>SabreSonic&#153;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, to power our
reservations and check-in capabilities along with a broad scope of technology for streamlining our
operations and improving revenues. This solution replaces Electronic Data Systems' </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Shares</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, a system we have used since our inception in 1994. With </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>SabreSonic</I></FONT><FONT
SIZE=2>, we will have access to real-time passenger data including the customer's history with Frontier and any EarlyReturns frequent
flyer activity, current travel plans and any changes made to an existing reservation. The data can be accessed by our customer service agents via an open-source, Windows-based interface at
all customer touch points including the website, reservations, the ticket counter and the gate, providing a seamless customer service experience from the time the customer books the ticket until they
arrive at their final destination. During the year ended March&nbsp;31, 2005 we incurred approximately $2,960,000 in costs associated with this transition. We anticipate further expenses in fiscal
year 2006 related to this system. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=47,EFW="2159467",CP="FRONTIER AIRLINES, INC.",DN="1",CHK=1030827,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK122:[05DEN6.05DEN2116]DO2116B.;7',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='14-JUN-2005;13:48' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dq2116_1_48"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We entered into an agreement with two vendors to market and sell all of our Boeing 737-200 and certain Boeing 737-300 spare parts inventories. We have completed
the process of transferring the initial inventory package to these vendors. We began to actively sell these parts in August&nbsp;2004. Once we have completed the required return condition
maintenance on the retired Boeing aircraft, we will sell the remaining Boeing spare parts. As of March&nbsp;31, 2005, the carrying value of our Boeing spare parts inventories totaled $7,060,000. As
we continue to have Boeing parts available for sale to these vendors, we will reflect the fair value of the rotables less selling costs. As of March&nbsp;31, 2005, we have recognized $744,000 in
gross proceeds resulting in a net gain on our expendable and rotable inventory totaling approximately $66,000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
continue to assess our liquidity position in light of our aircraft purchase commitments and other capital requirements, the economy, our competition, and other uncertainties
surrounding the airline industry. Prior to applying for a government guaranteed loan under the Stabilization Act, we filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission in
April&nbsp;2002 that allows us to sell equity or debt securities from time to time as market conditions permit. In September&nbsp;2003, we completed a public offering of 5,050,000 shares of our
common stock for approximately $81.1&nbsp;million, substantially all of which were used to prepay the government guarantee loan. As of March&nbsp;31, 2005, there is $64,150,000 remaining on the
shelf registration. We may need to continue to explore avenues to enhance our liquidity if our current economic and operating environment does not improve. We intend to continue to examine domestic or
foreign bank aircraft financing, bank lines of credit and aircraft sale-leasebacks, the sale of equity or debt securities, and other transactions as necessary to support our capital and
operating needs. For further information on our financing plans and activities and commitments, see "Contractual Obligations" and "Commercial Commitments" below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
expect to continue generating positive cash flow from our operations for the foreseeable future. We have obtained financing for all of our aircraft deliveries scheduled for calendar
years 2005 and 2006 and expect to have adequate liquidity to cover our contractual obligations. However, we cannot predict future trends or predict whether current trends and conditions will continue.
Our future liquidity and capital resources may be impacted by many factors, including "Risk Factors" in Item 1 of this report. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Contractual Obligations  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table summarizes our contractual obligations as of March&nbsp;31, 2005: </FONT></P>

March&nbsp;31, 2005, we had 14 loan agreements for nine Airbus A319 aircraft and five Airbus A318 aircraft. Two of the loans have a term of 10&nbsp;years and are payable in
equal monthly installments, including interest, payable in arrears. These loans require monthly principal and interest payments of $215,000 and $218,000, bear interest with rates of 6.71% and 6.54%,
with maturities in May and </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>August&nbsp;2011,
